thread.title: Kerry Stokes' gas plays Beach Energy and Drillsearch to merge
thread.title_full: Kerry Stokes' gas plays Beach Energy and Drillsearch to merge | afr.com

author: Brian Robins
title: Kerry Stokes' gas plays Beach Energy and Drillsearch to merge
text:
The consolidation of the oil and gas sector continues apace. Brendan Esposito by Brian Robins Two of the largest Cooper Basin plays, Drillsearch and Beach Energy, will merge to create a $1 billion-plus listed entity that will be 20 per cent owned by billionaire Kerry Stokes.
Mr Stokes' Seven Group Holdings has a near 20 per cent shareholding in the two companies and will emerge with the same-sized holding in the merged entity.
The merger follows an unsuccessful play this week for troubled Australian producer Santos along with the earlier unwelcome bid by Woodside Petroleum for PNG producer Oil Search .
The merger is via a scheme of arrangement, which will make it difficult for other parties to block the merger, although Beach has agreed to pay a break fee of $3.8 million to Drillsearch if the deal is broken off.
Drillsearch shareholders will receive 1.25 shares in Beach for every share held, which values Drillsearch at about $380 million. This is a premium of 27 per cent to Drillsearch's last traded price.
The merger will create a combined entity with production of 12.1 million barrels of oil equivalent.
This month, Citi analysts raised their recommendation on Beach to a "buy", pointing to the company's stated ambition of pursuing acquisitions to emerge as an ASX-50 company.
"Low oil prices are forcing asset sales as companies focus on fixing balance sheets," Citi told clients. "Beach Energy's Cooper JV partners Origin Energy and Santos are known sellers of the asset, and this is but one of many asset sales targeted globally.
 "Beach has stated that it is seeking growth in its core Cooper Basin through organic and inorganic opportunities. Therefore we think Beach is in prime position for any Cooper JV sales, as the only JV party with pre-emption rights with the desire for external growth, as well as other opportunities in Australia."
